page.title: 09CROOK'S CUMBRIAN LANDSCAPE
page.content: HILLS,TREES,ROCKS AND WATER FORM THE LANDSCAPE AROUND THE VILLAGE OF CROOK. HILLS ARE SMALL,THE HIGHEST POINT JUST 249 METRES ABOVE SEA LEVEL. TREES ARE DECIDUOUS AND CONIFEROUS.A VERY SMALL SECTION OF THE RIVER KENT FLOWS ACROSS ONE CORNER OF THE AREA. ITS RAPID DESCENT OVER 20 MILES MAKES IT THE FASTEST FLOWING RIVER IN THE NORTH OF ENGLAND.A SHORT SECTION OF THE SINGLE TRACK RAILWAY CONNECTING KENDAL AND WINDERMERE RUNS ALONGSIDE. DRY STONE WALLS FEATURE AS FIELD BOUNDARIES,LOOKING AS IF THEY HAD GROWN THERE RATHER THAN HAVING BEEN BUILT DURING THE MIDDLE OF THE 18TH CENTURY.SKILLED WALLERS ARE ALMOST A DYING BREED,BUT HERE A YOUNG LADY CARRIES ON THE TRADITION,AND IS OFTEN CALLED UPON TO REPAIR AND REBUILD WHEN NECESSARY.
